Fig. 14 Constructing PtLa@ZnBeta catalyst with single atomic Pt catalyzing propane dehydrogenation Wenli Zhao Investigation Rui Zhou Data curation Hongjiang Li Formal analysis Shenmin Li Supervision Yingna Cui Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Conceptualization ⁎ Xinping Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Conceptualization ⁎ College of Environment and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China College of Environment and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University Dalian 116622 China College of Environment and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Zn has been found to be the most effective metal that geometrically and electrically modifies Pt by forming intermetallic alloy with Pt, whereas it suffers from gradual losing during the reaction caused by volatilization. Herein, we propose a strategy introducing La3 + together with Pt2+ into the zeolite channels by ion-exchange that allow the La3+ anchoring onto zeolite framework Zn and acting as the successor of Zn by forming alloy with Pt whereby executing the task of isolating and stabilizing the Pt atoms when Zn lost during the PDH reaction. The 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst prepared in this way displayed much superior catalytic performance in PDH reaction than that of anchoring Pt2+ cations alone onto framework Zn. It is worthy to extend this strategy to other metals that is capable of forming intermetallic alloy with Pt but possesses high boiling point, to develop highly active, selective and catalytic stable PDH catalysts. Graphical Abstract Constructing PtLa@ZnBeta catalyst with single atomic Pt catalyzing propane dehydrogenation in the “three-step” strateg Keywords Ion-exchange PtLa Alloy ZnBeta Framework Zn PDH Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) as an important technology for the industrial production of propylene, has been favored by wide range of researchers in recent years due to shale gas exploitation increasing in the globes [1–5]. For the PDH, Oleflex technique utilizing PtSn/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has been developed, which overcame the environmental problem of catofin technique utilizing Cr-based catalyst [4,6]. Nevertheless, like the other commercial catalysts being applied in the PDH, the Pt-based catalyst suffers from fast deactivation due to Pt sintering and coke deposition on the catalyst surface, which has become the greatest challenge of this field in the last decade [4,6–8]. For the Pt metal, despite it alone possesses rather high catalytic activity to the PDH as well, the selectivity to propylene is not satisfactory and the deactivation of it caused by excessive dehydrogenation is much significant. It is known from the previous investigation that larger Pt ensembles significantly catalyze structure-sensitive side reactions, including cracking and deep dehydrogenation, which led to more cracking products (C1, C2) and quick coke formation [9]. Hence, besides Sn, numerous metal such as Ga [10,11], Y [12,13], In [14], Bi [15,16], Ce [17,18], Mn [19], Cu [20–22], Co [23], Fe [24], have also been extensively investigated as modifier to regulate the geometric and electronic features of the supported Pt metal in the past years. Of which, Zn displayed the most efficient effect for enhancing the selectivity of the catalyst and depressing coke deposition on Pt by forming alloy with Pt [25], especially in the case of utilizing zeolites as supports. Li and coworkers [26] have constructed Pt-Zn/Si-Beta catalyst by anchoring Pt sites on Zn species that are stabilized by silanol nest originated from Beta zeolite dealumination. The Pt-Zn/Si-Beta catalyst provided 76 mol⸱gPt −1⸱h−1 of propylene production rate with deactivation rate of ∼ 0.02 h−1 at 550 °C. Shin and coworkers [27] have prepared a PtZn-DML catalyst with 2D delaminated MWW layers (DML) supporting PtZn bimetallic nanoclusters. The catalyst converted 40.3 % of propane at 600 °C and WHSV of 11.8 h−1 up to 13.6 days with low deactivation rate < 0.002 h−1. For the zeolites, besides the surface silanols could serve as location sites to stabilize Zn species whereby inhibit the Pt-Zn alloy species aggregation and sintering, their unique microporous structure could play a role confining the Pt-Zn alloy species migration so as endow the catalyst with a superior antisintering and anticoking property under harsh reaction conditions when the Pt-Zn alloy species were encapsulated the species into the zeolite crystals in some ways [28]. Yu and co-workers [29] have encapsulated subnanometer PtZn clusters inside silicate-1 zeolite via a ligand-protected direct H2 reduction strategy, effectively avoided aggregation of the active metal species during reaction as well as in the catalyst regeneration process. Wu and co-workers [30] have prepared PtZn@Beta catalyst in a strategy of incorporating of Zn into Beta zeolite structure by the Zn@Beta zeolite synthesis with aid of ethylenediamine (EDA) and subsequent introducing Pt into the Zn@Beta support by impregnation. The catalyst exhibited initial propane conversion of 36.8 % at 550 °C and 4.7 h−1 combined with deactivation rate of 0.004 h−1. Wang and co-workers [31] have encapsulated PtZn bimetallic nanoparticles into high-silica SSZ-13 zeolites with aid of EDA as well but by one-pot synthesis. The 0.5Pt3Zn@SSZ-13 catalyst thus obtained displayed superior catalytic performance in successive operation-regeneration cycles. Wang and coworkers [32] have proposed an innovative strategy to construct Pt-Zn alloy catalyst, with which they obtained a S-1@0.1Pt9Zn@DPS-1 catalyst with the structure of isolated Pt atoms anchoring on ZnO nanoclusters that were highly dispersed S-1 zeolite and further encapsulated by defective porous S-1 zeolite (DPS-1). 40.7 % of propane was converted by the catalyst at 550 °C and WHSV of 0.47 h−1. Note that despite Zn could help Pt selectively and stably catalyze the PDH, the low boiling point of the metallic Zn (907 °C) made it gradually lose during the PDH reaction [26–36], leading to an irreversible deactivation of the catalysts, which brings to a new challenge to the researchers. To retard the deactivation, Tan and coworkers [35] have utilized enlarged quantity of Zn to construct Pt1Zn1 alloy sites over the BEA zeolite surface. They found that Zn-rich support surface is beneficial for stabilizing the Pt1Zn1 alloy sites and enhancing the coke resistance. Herein, we considered that, as a fundamental strategy overcoming the problem resulted from the Zn metal volatilization, it may be relying on the other metals that is capable of forming intermetallic alloy with Pt so as to isolates Pt atoms likes done by Zn, but possesses a high boiling point. In this work, we prepared PtLa@ZnBeta catalysts by means of the property of ZnBeta zeolite allowing Pt2+and La3+ cations getting into its channels and anchoring at framework Zn. We found that La could act as the successor of Zn well forming intermetallic alloy with Pt whereby executes the task of isolating and stabilizing the Pt atoms when Zn is lost during the PDH reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Supported and encapsulated two types of Pt catalysts were involved in this work, the preparation of them are separately described as follows: To prepare the supported type of Pt catalysts, two Beta zeolites were synthesized from the gels with molar ratio of 1 SiO2: 0.02 or 0.04 Al2O3: 0.11 K2O: 0.3 TEAOH: 15 H2O in the procedure reported in literature [37,38]. From ICP analysis, it is known that the two zeolites have Si/Al ratio of 23.2 and 11.1, respectively. To eliminate undesired acidic sites on the zeolite surface, the zeolites were subjected to dealumination before loading active and doping components according to the literature [39,40], and the resultant zeolite were denoted as deAlBeta-23.2 or deAlBeta-11.1 according to their actual Si/Al ratio before delamination. Series of 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 and 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 with different Zn contents x (0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.5, 1, 2, 3 wt%) as well as 0.1PtyY/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts with different Y contents y (0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1, 1.2 wt%) were prepared by sequential incipient wetness impregnation using Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2, Zn(NO3)2 and Y(NO3)3 as the metal precursors. The sequence is Zn or Y at first and then Pt. For 0.1Pt0.5La/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst, the preparation method was the same as that of the 0.1Pt0.5Y/deAlBeta-11.1, just utilizing La(NO3)3 instead of Y(NO3)3. After each one impregnation, the resultant mixture was calcined at 550 °C for 2 h. For the preparation of 0.1Pt0.5Zn0.5Y/deAlBeta-11.1, which contains 0.5 wt% Zn and 0.5 wt% Y, co-impregnation of Zn and Y prior to Pt has been done. For all of the supported type of catalysts mentioned above, they have the same Pt contents of 0.1 wt%. To prepare the encapsulated type of Pt catalysts, ZnBeta zeolites with Zn incorporation into the zeolite framework were firstly synthesized from the gels with mole composition 1.0 SiO2: 0.020 or 0.028 ZnO: 0.4 TEAOH: 0.05 K2O: 15 H2O using fumed silica as silicon source and zinc gluconate as zinc source. Typically, the synthesis was proceeded by adding appropriate amount of fumed silica to a mixed solution composed of designated amount of TEAOH, KOH, zinc gluconate and deionized water, stirring at 80 °C for 24 h. Subsequently the resultant gel was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave for a crystallization at 145 °C for 96 h. The solid product was separated by centrifugation and dried. Finely, they were calcined at 550 °C in air for 4 h. To make more Zn incorporate to zeolite framework, in some case, ethylene diamine (EDA) in EDA/Zn mole ratio 2 was additionally added to the gel utilized for the synthesis, with which to protect the Zn species to avoid ZnO formation. H-form of ZnBeta zeolite was applied for preparing encapsulated type of Pt catalysts unless stated otherwise, which is prepared by ion-exchanging the zeolites in 1 M NH4NO3 aqueous solution twice according to the literature [41,42]. The obtained H-form of ZnBeta zeolites were denoted as nZnBeta or nZnBeta(L), where the n indicates the nominal weight percent of Zn in the zeolite, while the L in the bracket indicates that organic ligand EDA was utilized in the synthesis. The encapsulated type of Pt catalysts was prepared by ion-exchange method, including the xPt@nZnBeta and xPtyLa@nZnBeta(L), where x and y indicates the nominal weight percentage of Pt and M in the catalyst, respectively, assuming the Pt(NH3)4 2+ and La3+ cations in the solution were thoroughly transferred to the zeolite tunnels by ion-exchange. For instance, the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) represents that the catalyst contains Zn, La and Pt with nominal weight percentage of 3 wt%, 0.32 wt% and 0.3 wt%, respectively. The ion-exchange was carried out by stirring the above mentioned H-form of zeolite powder in a solution containing Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 alone, or together with La(NO3)3 in a solution/solid ratio of 20 mL⸱g−1 at 80 °C for 8 h. After the ion-exchange, the solid was collected by centrifugation and dried at 120 °C for 5 h. Finally, it was calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts Ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectra of the ZnBeta zeolites were of recorded on a Hitachi U-3900H UV–vis spectrophotometer using dealuminated Beta zeolite as reference. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) of the samples were performed on a Smartlab 9kw X-ray diffractometer with scan steps of 0.01° and 5° min−1 for Beta zeolites at 40 kV and 200 mA, employing Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). In the case of ZnBeta zeolites, in order to know the precise 2θ degree of the diffraction peak, the scan was conducted at 2° min−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of the catalyst samples were performed on a JEOL Plus Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on JEM F200 field emission transmission electron microscope under a working voltage of 200 kV. The elemental analysis (mapping) of Pt, Zn and La were obtained using HAADF-STEM of energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mode. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Fisher super x spectrometer with the monochromatic Al-Kα X-rays as the excitation source. Binding energy of elements were determined by referencing the position of the adventitious C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. Before the measurement, the samples were ex-situ reduced in H2 at 600 °C for 2 h. The chemical compositions of the catalyst samples were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis that is carried out on carried out on Agilent 5100 ICP-OES spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the spent catalyst was carried out on TG 209 F3 Tarsus Analyser in air flow with a ramping rate of 20 K⸱min−1. 2.3 Catalytic activity test PDH reaction was carried out in a quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. In the activity test, the feed gas for the supported type of catalysts was C3H8: H2: N2 = 10: 10: 40 mL⸱min−1 while it was half decreased in the flow rate for the encapsulated type of catalysts. To adjust WHSV, different amount of catalyst was loaded to the reactor. The catalyst (40 ∼ 80 mesh) was treated at 600 °C on line in a gas mixture flow composed of 5 mL⸱min−1 H2 and 20 mL⸱min−1 N2 for 1 h before the reaction. Then it was cooled down to designated reaction temperature, and the gas flow was switched to the feed gas mixture for reaction. The products were analysed by online GC equipped with a plot Al2O3 capillary tube column (0.53 mm in diameter and 30 m in length). The propane conversion, propylene selectivity, carbon balance (CB) of the reaction, and the deactivation constant (k d) of the catalyst in long-term reaction period were respectively calculated in the Eqs. Initial ) t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Zn and Y modified Pt/deAlBeta catalysts Fig. 1 shows the SEM images and XRD patterns of the deAlBeta-23.2 (Fig. 1a) and deAlBeta-11.1 (Fig. 1b) that were utilized as supports preparing the Pt/deAlBeta catalysts. It is clear that both of the two zeolites have average crystal size of 200 ∼ 300 nm, and their morphology are indistinguishable from each other, despite of them originated from the parent Beta zeolites with different Si/Al ratio (23.2 or 11.1). Fig. 2 depicts propane conversion and propylene selectivity as a function of reaction time on stream over series of 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 and 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1. It can be found that both of the activity and the selectivity of the catalysts were largely influenced by the Zn content of the catalysts. For the 0.1Pt/deAlBeta-23.2 (Fig. 2a), not only the catalytic activity is much lower, which delivers an initial propane conversion of 2.9 %, the selectivity to propylene (86.6 %) is also much inferior to the other catalysts containing Zn. All of the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 catalysts containing Zn provided the propylene selectivity higher than 97 %. With the addition of Zn to the catalyst in the range of 0 ∼ 0.5 wt%, the activity of the catalysts drastically increased. Concurrently, carbon balance of the reaction over the catalyst was also improved. For instance, the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 catalyst with the Zn content 0.4 wt% delivered propane conversion of 17 % and carbon balance of 95 %, while over the catalyst with the Zn content of 0.5 wt%, the propane conversion and carbon balance increased to 23 % and 97 %, respectively under the same reaction conditions. When Zn content was further increased, for instance, to 1 wt%, as shown in the Fig. 2a, the changes both on the activity and on the carbon balance became insignificant, which just made the propane conversion increased from 23 % to 24 % and the carbon balance increased from 97 % to 98 %. Noticeably, over the deAlBeta-11.1 support, as shown in the Fig. 2b, the important functions of Zn modifying the catalytic property of Pt both on the selectivity and on the activity could be confirmed as well, large activity increase occurred when the Zn content of the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 was increased from 0.5 wt% to 2 wt%. It can be interpreted as that the lower Si/Al ratio of the parent zeolite allows the dealuminated zeolite support possessing more silanol hydroxyl nests to accept the Zn species, which eventually made more Zn species taken the role of anchoring and dispersing Pt [43]. By comparing Fig. 2a and b, it can be also found that although the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 are superior to the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 in catalytic property when the Zn content is larger than 1 wt%, the former one is actually inferior to the latter one in the case of Zn content less than 0.4 wt%. The results seem to be perplexing, whereas it can be reasonably interpreted by the roles of silanol nests acted in the catalyst structure construction and in the reaction. Despite the silanol nests are beneficial to the Zn dispersion by bonding Zn on the zeolite surface, so that positively contributes to the catalytic property, they play the bad role of strongly adsorbing propylene molecules, result in carbon deposition over the catalyst [44]. That is why the larger amount of silanol nests over the zeolite surface positively or negatively contribute to the catalytic property, eventually depended on the Zn content of the catalysts. Actually, it can be observed that the deactivation of 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts with the less Zn content (x = 0.2, 0.4) is faster than that of the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 (Fig. 2). Moreover, the propylene selectivity and the carbon balance in the reaction over two 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts (x = 0.2, 0.4) are also lower than the corresponding 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-23.2 catalysts. For instance, the propylene selectivity and carbon balance are respectively 98 % and 95 % over the 0.1Pt0.4Zn/deAlBeta-23.2, while they respectively became 97 % and 92 % in the case of 0.1Pt0.4Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst, which should be relevant to dissociation of the reactant and carbon deposition occurring over the much larger amount of rest silanol nests. More importantly, in the Fig. 2a and b, it can be also found that apart from the activity and selectivity, the catalytic stability was also significantly enhanced by adding appropriate amount of Zn to single Pt metal catalyst, which could be ascribed to the Pt-Zn alloy formation [45,46]. Fig. 3 displays the catalytic performance of series of 0.1PtyY/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts in the PDH reaction, which indicates that Y like Zn, could effectively improve the activity and selectivity of Pt in the catalysts. Nevertheless, the modifying effect of Y seems to be inferior compared with that of Zn in the selectivity as well as the catalytic stability. For instance, the propylene selectivity and carbon balance are 95.1 % and 96.5 %, respectively, over the 0.1Pt0.7Y/deAlBeta-11.1 with the optimum Y content 0.7 wt%, which is considerably less than the corresponding values of 98.6 % and 98.5 % given by the 0.1Pt2Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst (Fig. 2b). The propane conversion over the 0.1Pt0.7Y/deAlBeta-11.1 decreased to 19.7 % from 23.5 % when the reaction conducted for 4 h with time on steam, while no propane conversion change could be detected over 0.1Pt2Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 in this reaction period at the same reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 4, for the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts, despite the ones with Zn content higher than 0.5 wt% could remain their initial activity unchanged at 550 °C within 4 hours’ reaction, the activity of them depressed with time on stream as long as the reaction time exceeded to 10 hours. For the 0.1Pt3Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst, the only discrepancy to 0.1Pt2Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 in the catalytic performance is the deterioration, which is considerably slower than that of the latter. It means that, the deterioration for the 0.1PtxZn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalysts are also related with the Zn component losing, as indicated by literature [30–34]. Given that Zn loss would occur during the reaction, the 0.1Pt3Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst that has a higher Zn content were subjected to long-term reaction, and compared with 0.1Pt0.5Zn0.5Y/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst utilizing Y together with Zn as co-additives modifying Pt. As shown in this figure, the addition of 0.5 wt% of Y made the 0.1Pt0.5Zn0.5Y/deAlBeta-11.1 not only more active than the 0.1Pt0.5Zn/deAlBeta-11.1, but also more stable even than the 0.1Pt3Zn/deAlBeta-11.1 for catalyzing the reaction. The cause should be associated with the much higher boiling point of metal Y (3336 °C) than that of Zn (907 °C), which allows Pt-Y alloy [3,5,12,13] stable without Y losing during the reaction. Notably, the 0.1Pt0.5La/deAlBeta-11.1 catalyst with La alone modifying Pt displayed a catalytic stability tendency superior than that of 0.1Pt0.5Y/deAlBeta-11.1 (Fig. 4). It implies that, if Pt-La alloy species could be highly dispersed and separated by the zeolite substrate, a highly durable catalyst could be expected with the help of zeolite structure restraining the species sintering. 3.2 The Pt@ZnBeta catalysts For the Pt metal species catalysing the PDH, atomic Pt over the catalyst surface would be the ideal state able to active the C-H band of propane while without leading to excessive dehydrogenation [8,47,48]. If Pt ions could be introduced to the zeolite micropore and anchored to some special sites of the micropore surface, it would just be this case after reduction. Unfortunately, for an ordinary silica-aluminium Beta zeolite, despite the framework aluminium allows the Pt cations accessing to the zeolite channels in ion-exchange, it would results in carbon deposition under the reaction conditions due to the acidity [49]. Hence, silica-zinc zeolites able to make Pt cations entrancing to zeolite channels and anchoring on the framework Zn but without the undesired acidity were synthesized for preparing the Pt@ZnBeta type of catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns and UV–vis spectra of ZnBeta zeolites being intend as candidates to prepare the Pt@ZnBeta catalysts. In this figure, it can be known that the three ZnBeta zeolites, 2ZnBeta, 2ZnBeta(L) and 3ZnBeta(L), have the BEA topological structure same as that of the commercial silica-aluminium Beta zeolite, and crystallites being closed to the latter. It seems that, the only little discrepancy for the ZnBeta zeolites in the XRD patterns with respect to the commercial silica-aluminium Beta zeolite is that, the diffraction peak shifted to lower degrees, for instance, the peak for the silica-aluminium Beta zeolite at 22.5 ° shifted to 22.41 ∼ 22.43 ° in the case of ZnBeta zeolites (insert in Fig. 5a). It reflects the lattice expansion being caused by the substitution of Al3+ with Zn2+, as one of evidences of Zn incorporated to the zeolite framework [50]. Fig. 5b has also provided evidence for the Zn incorporation to the zeolite framework. All of the three ZnBeta zeolites exhibited strong absorption intensity at 190 nm, which is widely accepted as tetragonal coordinated Zn [47,51]. In this figure, it can be found that, the absorption intensities of the 2ZnBeta and 2ZnBeta(L) are almost identical. Whereas, more ZnO species, that delivers absorption in the range of 275 ∼ 375 nm, on the 2ZnBeta in comparison with that of 2ZnBeta(L) was observed in the UV–vis spectroscopy, despite they could not be detected by XRD even in the case of 2ZnBeta (Fig. 5a). It indicates that EDA did play a function of inhibiting ZnO formation [30,52]. Nevertheless, more intensive absorption in the range of 275 ∼ 375 nm but not at 190 nm on the 3ZnBeta(L) with respect to that of 2ZnBeta(L) was observed in the UV–vis spectra, indicating that the nominal content increasing of Zn from 2 wt% to 3 wt% just led to increment of the ZnO in the sample. No imparity either in the crystal morphology, average size (Fig. S3) or Zn dispersion within the ZnBeta zeolite crystal (Fig. S4, S5) was found in SEM images for the 2ZnBeta and 3ZnBeta (L), though the zeolites have different nominal Zn contents and come from different synthesis conditions. Fig. 6 and Fig. S6 show HAADF-STEM image and EDX element-mapping of the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) with actual Zn content of 3.433 wt% and Pt content of 0.185 wt% (Table S1). In these figures, it can be found that both of Zn and Pt appear in the whole catalyst particles without aggregation, indicating that the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst has an ideal dispersion of Zn and Pt. Fig. 7 shows the HRTEM image of the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L), which confirms that no aggregated Pt species formation within the 3ZnBeta(L) zeolite crystals and all of the Pt atoms located at the position of the zeolite crystal lattice. From these characterization results, we believed that, no matter the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) or the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalysts, they have the same catalytic structure that single Pt atoms anchoring at the zeolite framework Zn. The Pt@ZnBeta catalysts was investigated in the two Pt content level of 0.075 and 0.3 wt%, respectively. Fig. 8 shows the catalytic performance of the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta and 0.075Pt@K-2ZnBeta catalysts, which were prepared by Pt2+ ion-exchange on H-form or as-synthesized (without underwent NH4NO3 exchange) 2ZnBeta zeolites. Clearly, the catalytic performance for the 0.075Pt@K-2ZnBeta is much inferior than that of 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta, indicating that potassium exerts a negative effect on the catalytic activity. It is contrary to that reported in the literature on the supported type [15,53] and encapsulated type [54] of Pt catalysts. ICP analysis indicates that the 0.075Pt@K-2ZnBeta contains 0.046 wt% of Pt, which is quite closed to the Pt content 0.048 wt% of the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta (Table S1). The results mean that the inferior catalytic property for the 0.075Pt@K-2ZnBeta is not caused by the Pt content but other parameter, most probably the 0.466 wt% potassium of the catalyst (Table S1). Fig. 9 shows the catalytic performance of the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta and 0.075Pt@3ZnBeta(L) in long-term reaction conducted at 550 °C and the WHSV of 23.6 h−1. The two catalysts displayed almost a same catalytic performance with time on stream other than that exhibited in the first 2 hours’ reaction period. In this period, the activity for the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst is rapidly increased, whereas for the 0.075Pt@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst is drastically decreased (refer to the insert of this figure). The rapid activity decrease in the case of the 0.075Pt@3ZnBeta(L) may be resulted from gradual coverage of Pt by Zn that is originated from ZnO, since the 3ZnBeta(L) zeolite support contains more undesired ZnO, as detected by UV–vis spectra (Fig. 5b) and discussed before. After that, the activity of the two catalysts slowly elevated up until the reaction time on stream increased to 46 hours, and thereafter underwent a slow deactivation in patterns being closed to each other. These phenomena could be explained well by the gradual separation of Zn from the zeolite framework and losing during the reaction process [27,30]. The activity increasing of the catalysts appeared in the reaction period 2 ∼ 46 h should be the result of the more active intermetallic Pt1Zn1 alloy species exposing to the reactant with time on stream while the continued deactivation thereafter should be caused by excessive losing of Zn from the catalysts [30]. As indicated by ICP analysis, the Zn content for the fresh 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst is 2.512 wt% whereas it dropped to 0.063 wt% for the spent catalyst after the 400 hours’ long-term reaction (Table S1). To confirm the speculation, the actual Zn content of the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst that just reached its most active state upon undergoing 46 hours’ reaction (Fig. 9b) was also analyzed by ICP, which indicates that the most active structure contains 0.293 wt% of Zn. Thus, why the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst exhibited a “volcano” pattern of activity variation in the 400 hours’ reaction is already much clear. To get information about the carbon deposition over the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst during the long-term reaction as well as the regeneration property of the catalyst, a batch of fresh catalyst was subjected to 309 hours’ reaction under the same reaction conditions and then regenerated in air. As shown in Fig. 9b, its activity variation within the first 150 hours is substantially identical to the other several runs whereas the activity aviation this case deviated thereafter from that conducted for 400 hours (dash line in Fig. 9b). It reflects that quite little discrepancy of the catalyst in the Zn content, arising from the Zn lose during the reaction, significantly influences the catalytic performance. Quite limited activity recovery was observed no matter the regeneration of the catalyst had been done at 450 or 550 °C in air (Fig. 9b). The results indicate that the activity degradation of the catalyst is mainly caused by Zn losing but not carbon deposition over the catalyst. Note that, the regeneration process resulted in a rapid activity drop thereafter, indicating that the Pt species without the coexistence of Zn are much sensitive to air even at 450 °C. 3.3 The Pt@ZnBeta modified by La Fig. 10 shows Pt 4 f and Zn 2p XPS spectra of the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) and 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalysts comparing with those of 0.3Pt/S-1. Given that, some amount of Al may be existed in the samples arising from impurity of the deionized water, which would make the Pt 4 f5/2 confused due to the Al 2p feature covering this region, the Pt 4 f7/2 XPS of the three samples was discussed below. As shown in Fig. 10a, the Pt0 4 f7/2 binding energy for the 0.3Pt/S-1 sample appeared at 71.45 eV, while it shifted down to 71.05 eV in the case of 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L), which give evidence to that intermetallic Pt-Zn alloy was formed in the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst and that there is electron cloud density donation from Zn to Pt. On the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L), the Pt0 4 f7/2 bond energy further shifted down to 70.89 eV. It means that La has a strong interaction with Pt by donating electron cloud density to the latter even in the case of a larger amount of Zn existing in the catalyst. Zn 2p XPS spectra also provided the evidence to the electron cloud density donation. As shown in Fig. 10b, Zn0 2p1/2 binding energy on 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) and 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) are 1045.22 eV and 1045.36 eV, respectively, which are considerably higher than the general Zn0 2p1/2 binding energy of 1044.7 eV. To verify whether the La in the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst could act as the successor of Zn forming intermetallic alloy with Pt and whereby executes the task of isolating and stabilizing the Pt atoms when Zn is lost during the PDH reaction, the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst was subjected to a treating at 700 °C in H2 for 2 h so as to make most of Zn lost from the catalyst. The treatment delivered the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst containing only 0.177 wt% of Zn together with 0.179 wt% of Pt and 0.145 wt% of La (Table S1). Fig. 11 depicts the catalytic performance of the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst at different reaction temperatures. This catalyst provided 11 % of propane conversion even under the conditions 500 °C and WHSV of 59 h−1, with a propylene production rate of 78.8 molC3H6⸱gPt −1⸱h−1. In this figure, it can be also found that the deactivation caused by the Zn losing is still significant when the catalyst worked at 600 °C. Nevertheless, like that working at 500 and 550 °C, the catalyst at 600 °C delivered the carbon balance higher than 98.5 % in the reaction. Fig. 12 presents the catalytic performance of the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* compared with that of the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) in in long-term reaction being conducted at 550 °C. As shown in this figure, the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst displayed a “volcano” form of activity evolution with time on stream in WHSV of 59 h−1, being similar to that of the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst (Fig. 9), whereas the deactivation of the catalyst was rapider. This result reveals that the activity for the catalyst with higher Pt content is more sensitive to the Zn remaining in the catalyst. Interestingly, it can be found that in the case of 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst, despite it underwent a slow deactivation upon the reaction starting, the trend of the deactivation gradually decreased when the reaction over the catalyst exceeded to 300 hours and it eventually allows the propane conversion stabilized at a level of ∼14 %. During this reaction period, the catalyst delivered carbon balance in the level > 98 %, no regular change in carbon balance was observed. Note that, for the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst, the last retained activity can be understood as the contribution of PtLa alloy species being gradually formed during the reaction process accompanying with the Zn losing. To exclude the contribution coke deposition on the catalyst deactivation, the catalyst was then subjected to a treating with H2 on line at 600 °C for 1 h to eliminate the deposited coke [30,55] and the activity was subsequently tested again. As shown in this figure, although the propane conversion was elevated in some extent by this treating, it rapidly dropped back. It indicates that the primary cause leading to the deterioration of the catalyst in the early reaction stage is the loss of Zn in the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst, but not coke deposition. The composition of the catalyst after the reaction-regeneration-reaction cycle was analyzed by ICP (Table S1), which indicates that just quite little amount of Zn (0.012 wt%) retaining in the spent catalyst, while the losses of Pt and La are negligible. The results confirm that the activity of the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* at the last stage (in the 400 ∼ 600 hours’ reaction period) is actually contributed from the species formed from 0.160 wt% Pt and 0.143 wt% La within the Bata zeolite crystals. Fig. 13 shows HAADF-STEM image, EDX element-mapping and TG pattern (in air) of the spent 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst. No large PtLa alloy particles coming from a possible species aggregation appears in the whole field, neither for the bright-field imaging nor dark-field imaging, even though the catalyst underwent a special treatment (700 °C for 2 h) and 600 hours’ reaction. It indicates that the PtLa alloy species thus formed in the zeolite channels are rather stable so that capable of withstanding the special treatment as well as the harsh reaction conditions without sintering. In the EDX element-mapping, no matter the one focused on La (Fig. 13f) or on Pt (Fig. 13g), a “running person” image is dimly visible. Whereas, in the cases focused on Zn (Fig. 13e), this image is hardly identified. This is different from that of the 0.3Pt@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst, in which the catalyst particle image could be identified in the element-mapping focused on Zn (Fig. 6d). The phenomena can be well interpreted by the Zn loss arising from the special treatment (700 °C for 2 h) and subsequent 600 hours’ reaction. Note that, in Fig. 13d, the “running person” image is also hardly identified by carbon element-mapping for the spent 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalyst. Moreover, the TG pattern of the spent catalyst (Fig. 13h) shows that just 0.7 wt% of carbon over the catalyst surface. All of the characterization indicate that the Zn loss during the reaction is severe while the carbon deposition over the catalyst is not significant. Fig. 14 compared the HRTEM images of the fresh and spent 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* catalysts, in which it can be found that for the spent 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)*, it has almost no large difference from the fresh one in the structure. That is, all of heavy metals (Pt, La and their intermetallic alloy species) that delivers light spots still regularly located at lattice points despite the spent catalyst had been subjected to a long reaction period, which further corroborates the active structure PtLa@ZnBeta originated from the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* is stable enough for withstanding the harsh reaction conditions without sintering. 4 Conclusions ZnBeta zeolite with framework Zn has unique property that could introduce single Pt and other metal cations to the zeolite by ion-exchange while without undesired acidic sites remaining on the resultant catalyst surface. Since the Pt2+ cations are capable of anchoring at the position of framework Zn and forming intermetallic alloy species with Zn, the Pt being introduced to the ZnBeta zeolite channels could be dispersed to atomic level existing as intermetallic alloy species with Zn after reduction. As the Zn in the catalyst obtained in this way formed intermetallic alloy with Pt on one hand and has strong interaction with the zeolite structure on the other hand, it could not only stabilize itself in some extent but also the alloy species by anchoring them to the zeolite structure. Due to this reason, the 0.075Pt@2ZnBeta catalyst provided as high as 270.48 molC3H6·gPt −1·h−1 propane production rate with a deactivation constant (k d) of 0.0025 h−1 in a long-term reaction period of 400 hours (total reaction time) (Table S2). Being related to lower boiling point, the Zn component gradually lost during the reaction, which made Pt@ZnBeta catalyst hardly get rid of deactivation under the harsh reaction conditions of the PDH. The strategy of introducing La together with Pt to the ZnBeta zeolite channels in the way of ion-exchange could make La acted as the successor of Zn by forming alloy with Pt whereby execute the task of isolating and stabilizing the Pt atoms when Zn lost during the PDH reaction. This strategy allowed the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)* providing as high as 82.47 molC3H6·gPt −1·h−1 propane production rate with a deactivation constant (k d) of 0.0017 h−1 in a long-term reaction period 500 h (Table S2). Clearly, it can be considered that the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst would be more active than the 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L)*. Clearly, this strategy is worthy to extend to other metals that is capable of forming intermetallic alloy with Pt but possesses high boiling point, to develop more active, selective and catalytic stabile PDH catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Zn has been found to be the most effective metal that geometrically and electrically modifies Pt by forming intermetallic alloy with Pt, whereas it suffers from gradual losing during the reaction caused by volatilization. Herein, we propose a strategy introducing La3 + together with Pt2+ into the zeolite channels by ion-exchange that allow the La3+ anchoring onto zeolite framework Zn and acting as the successor of Zn by forming alloy with Pt whereby executing the task of isolating and stabilizing the Pt atoms when Zn lost during the PDH reaction. The 0.3Pt0.32La@3ZnBeta(L) catalyst prepared in this way displayed much superior catalytic performance in PDH reaction than that of anchoring Pt2+ cations alone onto framework Zn. It is worthy to extend this strategy to other metals that is capable of forming intermetallic alloy with Pt but possesses high boiling point, to develop highly active, selective and catalytic stable PDH catalysts.
